articles.headline: Big Board Aims to Keep an Upstart at Bay, but Copy Its Technology
articles.snippet: While the Investors Exchange awaits official status from the S.E.C., the New York Stock Exchange wants to adopt its would-be rival’s trading innovation.
articles.abstract: While the Investors Exchange awaits official status from the S.E.C., the New York Stock Exchange wants to adopt its would-be rival’s trading innovation.
articles.lead_paragraph: They say imitation is the sincerest form of flattery, but is the nation’s top securities cop letting the New York Stock Exchange carry that a bit too far?

articles.headline: Small, Piecemeal Mergers in Health Care Fly Under Regulators’ Radars
articles.snippet: As “creeping consolidation” deals add up — a hospital here, a doctors’ office there — they raise questions on where antitrust officials should focus their attention.
articles.abstract: As “creeping consolidation” deals add up — a hospital here, a doctors’ office there — they raise questions on where antitrust officials should focus their attention.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal officials are expected to argue in court starting Monday that a large hospital merger in the Chicago area could hurt consumers and should be stopped. It would be the latest in a series of efforts by regulators to push back against a wave of consolidation among major health care providers.

articles.headline: The Voter Support Agency Accused of Suppressing Votes
articles.snippet: The federal Election Assistance Commission was supposed to make casting ballots easier. Critics say it is trying to drive some would-be voters away.
articles.abstract: The federal Election Assistance Commission was supposed to make casting ballots easier. Critics say it is trying to drive some would-be voters away.
articles.lead_paragraph: The federal Election Assistance Commission was formed after the disputed 2000 election between George W. Bush and Al Gore and given an innocuous name and a seemingly inoffensive mission: to help state election officials make it easier to vote.

articles.headline: Once a Bright Spot, Afghan Telecoms Face Unsustainable Losses
articles.snippet: Cellphone providers challenged by the loss of potential customers and hurt by new taxes are trying to expand services and bring more Afghans online.
articles.abstract: Cellphone providers challenged by the loss of potential customers and hurt by new taxes are trying to expand services and bring more Afghans online.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Men thread their way through this city’s traffic jams, hawking streamers of phone cards. Others stand behind crude wooden tables selling cheap Chinese-made mobile phones. Throngs of people navigate the sidewalks and streets with cellphones pressed to their ears.

articles.headline: Getting a Student Loan With Collateral From a Future Job
articles.snippet: An alternative financing arrangement will let students pledge some of their future income for monetary assistance now.
articles.abstract: An alternative financing arrangement will let students pledge some of their future income for monetary assistance now.
articles.lead_paragraph: At Purdue University, some undergraduates will have a new option to help finance their degrees: pledging to pay a percentage of their future incomes in return for funds today.

articles.headline: Hastert Molested at Least Four Boys, Prosecutors Say
articles.snippet: In a court filing, prosecutors said they believed the former speaker of the House should face up to six months in prison when he is sentenced on April 27.
articles.abstract: In a court filing, prosecutors said they believed the former speaker of the House should face up to six months in prison when he is sentenced on April 27.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Federal prosecutors on Friday for the first time provided details of sexual abuse allegations against J. Dennis Hastert, the former speaker of the House, asserting that he molested at least four boys, as young as 14, when he worked as a high school wrestling coach decades ago.
articles.byline: By Monica Davey and Mitch Smith

articles.headline: Olympus Investigation Shows Ethical Lapses and a Caterer With Clout
articles.snippet: Two years after admitting to accounting fraud, Olympus hired its cafeteria operator to handle a dispute with Chinese customs authorities. Soon after, the case was inexplicably dropped.
articles.abstract: Two years after admitting to accounting fraud, Olympus hired its cafeteria operator to handle a dispute with Chinese customs authorities. Soon after, the case was inexplicably dropped.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Managers at an Olympus factory in southern China struggled for years to resolve a thorny dispute with local customs authorities. The problem risked incurring millions of dollars in fines and harming a crucial manufacturing hub that churned out 50 million camera lenses a year.

articles.headline: (Legal) Moonshiner and University Battle Over Rights to ‘Kentucky’
articles.snippet: When Colin Fultz opened a gourmet distillery and tried to trademark his business name, Kentucky Mist Moonshine, the University of Kentucky said, Whoa.
articles.abstract: When Colin Fultz opened a gourmet distillery and tried to trademark his business name, Kentucky Mist Moonshine, the University of Kentucky said, Whoa.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHITESBURG, Ky. — Moonshine packs a punch in this corner of Appalachia, where making hooch is steeped in local lore. But when Colin Fultz, the grandson of a bootlegger, opened a gourmet distillery here last fall, he ran afoul of a spirit even more potent than white lightning: University of Kentucky basketball.

articles.headline: As Campaigns Seek Delegates, Ordinary Voters Feel Sidelined
articles.snippet: As Americans flock this year to outsider candidates, they are suddenly waking up to the reality that the process for picking the parties’ nominees involves ordinary voters in only an indirect way.
articles.abstract: As Americans flock this year to outsider candidates, they are suddenly waking up to the reality that the process for picking the parties’ nominees involves ordinary voters in only an indirect way.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When it comes to nominating presidential candidates, it turns out the world’s foremost democracy is not so purely democratic.

articles.headline: The Female Viagra, Undone by a Drug Maker’s Dysfunction
articles.snippet: Missteps by Valeant, along with aggressive accounting practices and unusual business relationships, derailed one of the most intriguing drugs in a generation.
articles.abstract: Missteps by Valeant, along with aggressive accounting practices and unusual business relationships, derailed one of the most intriguing drugs in a generation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last August, Sprout Pharmaceuticals had a new pill on its hands that quickly captured the nation’s imagination. The Food and Drug Administration had just approved its drug Addyi to treat low sex drive in women.
articles.byline: By Katie Thomas and Gretchen Morgenson

articles.headline: Only Hard Choices for Parents Whose Children Flirt With Terror
articles.snippet: Hoping for an intervention, Sal Shafi cooperated with the government when his son showed warning signs of radicalization. A year later, his son was in handcuffs, facing 20 years in prison.
articles.abstract: Hoping for an intervention, Sal Shafi cooperated with the government when his son showed warning signs of radicalization. A year later, his son was in handcuffs, facing 20 years in prison.
articles.lead_paragraph: FREMONT, Calif. — The banging on the door jolted Sal Shafi awake. F.B.I. agents were looking for his son. “Where’s Adam?” they yelled. “Where’s Adam?”

articles.headline: Climate-Related Death of Coral Around World Alarms Scientists
articles.snippet: Researchers believe that bleaching, which they attribute to heat stress compounded by climate change, is threatening more than a third of the planet’s reefs.
articles.abstract: Researchers believe that bleaching, which they attribute to heat stress compounded by climate change, is threatening more than a third of the planet’s reefs.
articles.lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Kim Cobb, a marine scientist at the Georgia Institute of Technology, expected the coral to be damaged when she plunged into the deep blue waters off Kiritimati Island, a remote atoll near the center of the Pacific Ocean. Still, she was stunned by what she saw as she descended some 30 feet to the rim of a coral outcropping.

articles.headline: Revelation on Brussels Attackers Fuels Fears of New Assaults
articles.snippet: News that militants in Belgium had planned to strike in France was a reminder that much is still unknown about the Islamic State’s networks in Europe.
articles.abstract: News that militants in Belgium had planned to strike in France was a reminder that much is still unknown about the Islamic State’s networks in Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The announcement on Sunday that the plotters of last month’s Brussels terror attacks had originally intended to hit Paris again only heightened the concern among police and intelligence agencies that shadowy Islamic State networks could unleash new attacks at any time, not only in France and Belgium but in other European capitals.
articles.byline: By Alissa J. Rubin and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: For Staff on ‘Naked and Afraid,’ Work Is Just a Blur
articles.snippet: To make the Discovery Channel reality show suitable for family television viewing, five full-time visual effects artists labor behind the scenes.
articles.abstract: To make the Discovery Channel reality show suitable for family television viewing, five full-time visual effects artists labor behind the scenes.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHERMAN OAKS, Calif. — At first blush, it is a perfectly normal modern production office: standing desks, an indoor putting green, a casual dress code. There is a Whole Foods right around the corner.

articles.headline: Paul Ryan, a Mirage Candidate, Wages a Parallel Campaign
articles.snippet: The speaker of the House is already deep into a national campaign — one he calls “Confident America” — but it is not necessarily aimed at the presidency.
articles.abstract: The speaker of the House is already deep into a national campaign — one he calls “Confident America” — but it is not necessarily aimed at the presidency.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the Republican candidates for the White House battled in Wisconsin last week, Speaker Paul D. Ryan was conspicuously absent from his home state — but he was very much on the political stage.

articles.headline: G.M. Begins Prevailing in Lawsuits Over Faulty Ignition Switches
articles.snippet: After spending more than $2 billion settling claims, General Motors has started winning lawsuits related to the gravest safety crisis in its history.
articles.abstract: After spending more than $2 billion settling claims, General Motors has started winning lawsuits related to the gravest safety crisis in its history.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — After two years of heavy legal and financial consequences, General Motors has finally turned the tide and started winning lawsuits related to the gravest safety crisis in its history.

articles.headline: Panama Papers Leak Signals a Shift in Mainstream Journalism
articles.snippet: The tentative merger between the Fourth Estate and the Fifth Estate takes another step as the rules change in the business of unearthing secrets.
articles.abstract: The tentative merger between the Fourth Estate and the Fifth Estate takes another step as the rules change in the business of unearthing secrets.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Four years passed between The New York Times’s first article based on the Pentagon Papers and the end of the Vietnam War.

articles.headline: Intuit Sheds Its PC Roots and Rises as a Cloud Software Company
articles.snippet: Intuit’s willingness to change course was an asset when Xero established itself as a clear alternative to QuickBooks, especially in foreign markets.
articles.abstract: Intuit’s willingness to change course was an asset when Xero established itself as a clear alternative to QuickBooks, especially in foreign markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — Three decades ago, at the dawn of the personal computer age, Intuit shook up the financial software world with its first product, Quicken. The program, which was centered on the simple notion of a virtual checkbook, suddenly made the PC a very useful tool for people to manage the chores of paying bills and tracking personal finances.

articles.headline: A Brussels Mentor Who Taught ‘Gangster Islam’ to the Young and Angry
articles.snippet: The network that Khalid Zerkani helped nurture in the district of Molenbeek has emerged as a central element in the Paris and Brussels attacks.
articles.abstract: The network that Khalid Zerkani helped nurture in the district of Molenbeek has emerged as a central element in the Paris and Brussels attacks.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — He lived under the rafters in a small attic apartment in the Molenbeek district of Brussels, and became known to some followers as the Santa Claus of jihad. He had the bushy beard and potbelly, and generously offered money and advice to young Muslims eager to fight in Syria and Somalia, or to wreak havoc in Europe.
articles.byline: By Andrew Higgins and Kimiko de Freytas-Tamura

articles.headline: In California, Marijuana Is Smelling More Like Big Business
articles.snippet: New rules are making it easier for cannabis farmers to operate, and voters are expected to legalize recreational use, drawing more commercial interest.
articles.abstract: New rules are making it easier for cannabis farmers to operate, and voters are expected to legalize recreational use, drawing more commercial interest.
articles.lead_paragraph: ADELANTO, Calif. — After decades of thriving in legally hazy backyards and basements, California’s most notorious crop, marijuana, is emerging from the underground into a decidedly capitalist era.

articles.headline: Donald Trump and New York Tabloids Resume Their Elaborate Dance
articles.snippet: For next week’s primary, Mr. Trump will return to the ink-stained caldron in which he and the media that he fed thrived in the 1980s.
articles.abstract: For next week’s primary, Mr. Trump will return to the ink-stained caldron in which he and the media that he fed thrived in the 1980s.
articles.lead_paragraph: As New York City newspaper assignments go, this was a delicate one. Fly to Florida. Walk into Donald J. Trump’s hospital room. Witness the birth of his second daughter.

articles.headline: As Oil Nations Consider a Freeze, Looking for Tensions to Thaw
articles.snippet: All eyes will be on this weekend’s meeting of OPEC members and Russia, watching for signs that they can cooperate enough to exercise market discipline.
articles.abstract: All eyes will be on this weekend’s meeting of OPEC members and Russia, watching for signs that they can cooperate enough to exercise market discipline.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — When officials from OPEC, Russia and some other oil-producing countries meet this weekend in Doha, Qatar, to discuss freezing petroleum production at current levels, the session’s significance might have more to do with style than substance.
